gist: grand larceny (amount > $1,000 or taken from a person directly)
description: stealing property worth more than $1k or directly from the person of another

gist: petit larceny (amount < $1,000 and not taken from a person directly)
description: stealing property in a way that doesn't meet the grand larceny qualifications

gist: larceny of merchandise held for sale in retail or wholesale establishments
description: larceny of merchandise held for sale in retail or wholesale establishments

gist: larceny of aircraft, automobile or other automotive driven vehicle, construction equipment or farm equipment
larceny of a personal dog or larceny of a fowl, horse, cow, sheep, etc. for animal husbandry purposes
cf_cm_notes: Larceny of pet dogs is considered normal larceny and depends on value and manner to determine felony / misdemeanor. Larceny of any domestic Fowl / horse / jackass / cow / etc, however, is instant Grand Larceny / felony

gist: larceny of crude oil or gasoline or any product thereof
cf_cm_notes: Depends on the value, $1,000 is the cutoff

gist: larceny of lost property under circumstances where it could reasonably have been returned to its rightful owner
cf_cm_notes: $1,000 cutoff for CM / CF. There are also additional penalties at $2,500 and $15,000

title: NA
gist: NA
buying, receiving, or concealing stolen property
cf_cm_notes: Felony if it's above $1,000 it's a felony, if it's less it's a misdemeanor

gist: breaking and entering while somebody is present
description: breaking into a building while someone is there and stealing stuff

gist: breaking and entering while nobody is present with intent to steal or commit a felony
description: breaking into a building while nobody is there and stealing stuff

gist: breaking and entering into any automobile, truck, trailer, etc with intent to steal or commit a felony (e.g. catalytic converters)
description: breaking into a car and stealing stuff

gist: poss. burglary tools
description: possessing burglary tools with intent to commit a crime

clean_charge_description: Entering with Intent To Commit a Crime
gist: entering w/ intent to commit some crime that doesn't meet the requirements for burglary
description: entering w/ intent to commit any felony, larceny, or malicious mischief, or entering w/out permission

clean_charge_description: Possession of Burglar's Tools (After Prior Conviction)
gist: poss. burglary tools after conviction
description: possessing burglary tools with intent to commit a crime after prior burglary conviction

title: NA
gist: NA
simple assault and/or simple battery
assault and/or battery w/ dangerous weapon
domestic assault and/or battery
cf_cm_notes: It's only a felony when a weapon is involved, second or subsequent offense against a pregnant woman, or resulting in great bodily harm.

gist: domestic assault and/or battery w/ dangerous weapon
assault and/or battery against one of several kinds of public official
notes: There are a ton of different versions of this with specific penalties and stuff, it's probably not worth trying to get seperate cleaned descriptions for all of them, but might need to revisit at some point.

title: NA
gist: NA
burning down a building with people in it (or a building that reasonably could have people in it, like an empty hotel), either on on purpose or while attempting to manufacture a CDS
burning down a building without people in it, either on purpose or while attempting to manufacture CDS
burning down any other property valued over $50 but not covered by 1401-1402 (e.g. a car, crops, pasture lands, etc.)
attempting and failing to burn down any property covered by 1401-1403

title: NA
gist: NA
covers several specific instances of fraud, including "defrauding an inkeeper / restaurant", "false pedigree of animals", "misrepresentation in selling trees, plants or shrubs", etc.
notes: It makes more sense to me to roll this into "Fraud (False Pretense / Deception)" or even just "Other / Unspecified", but they're in different parts of the statute so idk

gist: covers several specific instances of this type of fraud, including pretending to be married, identity theft, pretending to be a cop, etc.

writing a false / bogus check. This can get complicated, but generally you have to make two or more bogus checks totalling $2k in pursuance of a common scheme or plan (a felony), or you have to write two or more bogus checks between $500-$2k with or without some kind of scheme (a misdemeanor).
cf_cm_notes: If the amount is is less than $2k but over $500, and there is no "common scheme or plan to cheat and defraud", then it's a misdemeanor. Otherwise, it's a felony

gist: basically "tricking someone so you can get a thing worth up to $1,000", can include confidence games, bogus checks, fraudulent representation, etc.
notes: This technically includes "bogus check" and arguably even the credit card stuff, the only reason I broke it out is because there are so many in the data.

gist: there are several individual laws within section 1550, covering all kinds of credit / debit card crimes.
using a false weight / scale / etc. to defraud people
notes: I can't find any of these in the data

gist: the specific types of forgery get very hyperspecific, so this covers any instance of forgery in chapter 63, including first, second, and third degree forgery
cf_cm_notes: Depends on the specific thing forged and the dollar value
notes: There are actually 3 degrees of forgery, and we might want to try to separate those out at some point. However, I'm seeing mostly unspecified ones in the data (e.g. "UTTERING FORGED INSTRUMENTS") so I don't think it's worth it until we have a real reason to

gist: any kind of fraud specific to corporate affairs or insurance companies. i.e. chapter 64 and 65
notes: Mostly appears as "MAKING FALSE ENTRY IN CORPORATE RECORDS"

gist: defauding a creditor or making false statements about one's solvency with respect to repayment of debts to the creditor
notes: I only found literally one of these in the data

title: NA
gist: NA
parent / guardian neglecting or refusing to compel child to attend school
notes: Each day the child remains out of school after the oral and documented or written warning has been given to the parent, guardian, custodian, child or other person or the child has been ordered to school by the juvenile court shall constitute a separate offense.

gist: speeding 1-10 miles over
notes: includes oper not reasonable and proper

gist: mantory seatbelt use
children under 8 must be in propor restraint system
driving while license under suspension or revocation
license must be in immediate possession while driving
includes a lot of provisions mostly related to tags/registration, original VIN, vehicle weights.
notes: expired tag, false tag, no tag, selling fake tag, altered tag, in-state resident must have in-state tag or register it as a nonresident vehicle. vehicle cant exceed registered laden weight, providing false information for vehicle registration, operating a commercial vehicle without lettering requirements, and several regarding manufactured home registrations.

gist: compulsory insurance law
DUI or APC
description: driving, operating, or being in actual physical control of a motor vehicle while under the influence of any intoxicating substance
cf_cm_notes: It's a CM the first time and a felony afterwards
notes: DUI and APC are in the same statute and have the same penalties

gist: poss. CDS w/ intent

gist: distributing CDS
description: distributing a CDS. Also applies to counterfiet CDS or imitation

gist: poss. CDS

gist: maintaining a place to commit a CDS related crime
larceny of CDS
notes: This can sometimes be used to charge simple possession as a felony  and sidestep SQ 780

gist: CDS paraphernalia

gist: failure to affix tax stamp to CDS
CDS-related fraud

operator of mv refusing to stop for officer
